captions.text:
- Nice to see you, too.
- Did you have a good holiday?

- I did, I did.
We went to, uh--
It was the...French people year.

[laughter]
- You went with--

- So, you know--you know my wife
is French, so--

- Yes.
- So we went over to France

this year to visit them,
you know, in Paris.

- With her whole family?
- Yeah, yeah.

Well, they're there,
so we went over.

But here's the thing:
whenever we go to Europe,
go to France,

my wife doesn't let me handle
the money.

[laughter]
'Cause I have no respect
for the Euro.

- No?
- No, 'cause it's pretty.

You know, it's like--
it looks like play money.

You know, it's--
- It is, yeah.

You know, it's, like, green,
and some bills are blue.

Some of them are smaller
than the other ones.

So, it's like--
I'm just throwing it around.

- Yeah.
[laughter]

- Throwing it around.
- Wow.
- And over there, you know,
there's not really any tipping.

- I know!
- So, [stammering].

Do you do that?
Can you get used to that?

- No, and in Australia, as well.
You don't tip.

- Yeah, because you know,
they have this novel idea
of when you have a business,

you actually just pay
your employees yourself.

- Wow, what a--
[laughter]

[applause]
What a novel idea.

[cheers and applause]
- Crazy!
And they have health insurance,

so you know,
there's no tipping, so,

you know, we'll go
to a restaurant, and

you know, the wife--Alex--
will just leave,

like a couple of coins there!
It looks like two nickels,
and I'm like, "What the?"

That's embarrassing!
So I always find a reason
to go back, you know?

Like I'll say,
"Oo, I left my gloves."

And I go back,
and then throw one of those

pretty little blue fives down.
[laughter]

It just makes me feel better.
- Wow.

- So, yeah.
- What is the blue five worth,
do you know?

"Cinq," five--yeah.
Five euro.

So it's probably equal--
- Seven?

- Equivalent to, like,
100 bucks.

- Yeah, yeah.
[laughter]

Wow, that's the exchange
right now.

And the twins, they obviously
went with you, and...

- Yeah.
- Do they like going over there?

- They love it over there.
They love it over there.

And you know, of course,
the French is very strong,
the language, so--

- They speak, equally,
English and French.

- More--more French...
- Really?

- than English, but you know,
I think they're cursing.

- I think my--
[laughter]

I think they're cursing
in French,

'cause, you know, like,
I hear something, and I'm like,
"Alex, I think they're cursing."

She's like, "Oh, no.
No, no, baby.

They don't curse,
they don't curse."

- She's still smoking like that?
- Yeah.

- Okay.
- Yeah.

- So...
[laughter]
So then, you know,

She came to me the other day
and she said,

"Uh, you have to watch your
language."

And I'm like, "Why?"
She's like, "Uh,
the children, they are cursing."

And I'm like,
"Yeah, I told you that.

In French."
- Yeah.

- And she's like,
"No, they curse in English now.

I'm like, "Well, I guess
they curse in both languages.

That's good for them."
- Yeah.
[laughter]

They know cursing in
both languages.

Now when they speak English,
do they have a French accent?
- Uh, yes.

- That's adorable.
- Yes.
It--well...
[laughter]

- No?
- It is!

As long as they stay in
the French school.

You know,
they go to regular school,

they gonna beat
the hell out of 'em.
[laughter]

They just gonna get picked on!
- Oh, no.

And do they wear little berets
and wear French little outfits?

- Yeah, yeah, and I paint their
face in mime, too, Ellen.
What the hell is wrong with you?
[laughter]

- Yeah, we just give 'em that
baguette, and

little beret and mime face
and off to school!
On their imaginary bike.
[laughter]
What the hell is wrong with you?
- That's what I would do.

comments.text:
I was reading other comments and found myself interested in the topic of 
tipping around the world. If you aren't American, please comment. I am 
interested in knowing about other countries and their "rules" of tipping.

P.S. I've read alot of the comments and have yet to see someone really 
explain why we tip so here it is. 
Americans aren't "required" to tip, it's just courtesy mainly because 
workers are underpaid. When minimum wage was $7.25, my mom's friend said 
she made only $2 and some change. The tip is basically their paychecks and 
it is "courtesy" to tip 20%(?) of the bill. 
Hope this helps you understand a bit better.﻿
comments.author: rko32491

comments.text:
In France we have a minimal wage which is quite high. That means that we 
don't always tip, even though we will sometimes. (And we don't leave more 
than 1 or 2€, depending on the service.) (2€~$2.5)
comments.author: Glad Drago

comments.text:
I'm from Denmark and we don't tip here. The minimum wage for young people 
is like 10 dollars per hour and like 20 dollars for adults, so there are no 
reason for tipping. At our home when the pizza delivery guy delivers our 
pizza we always tip since we live on 5th floor and there is no elevator in 
the building
comments.author: MeVonKo

comments.text:
I can give you a bit of info.

In Lithuania (in the north east of Europe) it is normal to tip, usually a 
few coins, for example, if your bill is 17.80 euros, the majority will 
leave a 20 on the table and leave. I find that the better the place, the 
more mandatory tipping seems. I almost never see any tipping in coffee 
places like Starbucks or fast food restaurants, but if you are constantly 
taken care by a rushing waiter, who treats you well and with a smile, 99% 
of customers will leave some tip.
In Spain where I used to live, I can say for sure that tipping is NOT 
common at all. I was shocked to see that after hours of sitting at a bar 
table, treating themselves to plenty of drinks and snacks, my friends would 
pick up every little bit of their change and leave absolutely nothing for 
the waiter. We discussed this and as it was said in the interview, Spanish 
people don't see the point in paying more for a service that's already 
overpriced (have in mind that waiters get at least the minimum wage, 
usually a little bit more - around 1000 euros per month, health insurance 
included, so the society doesn't feel obligated to help out).
When I worked as a waitress myself for one summer in a Scandinavian bar, I 
had two types of customers: those who tipped immensely (from 20 to more 
euros per order), and those who tipped with cents which is truly petty and 
I would have preferred no tip at all. This is the only time I experienced 
this sort of strange tipping traditions.

In general, tipping in all European countries has a sense of generosity. 
You feel like tipping a waiter who has welcomed you with a smile and with 
whom you've connected (chatted a bit and so on). This is one of the reasons 
why workers in other areas of service are rarely tipped - if you don't 
engage with them as much, the tip doesn't come to mind. It is first and 
foremost an expression of generosity and sympathy.
comments.author: Imbra Kim

comments.text:
Okay, for example in Czech republic (middle Europe), when you're satisfied 
with the service, it's polite to leave a tip (should be around 10% of the 
bill - not to sound like a mockery). It's up to customer really. But it is 
polite to tip. I was a waitress in different types of ...buisness 
(restaurant, hotel, pizzeria) and I mostly got a good tipping :) In some 
places, the tip is for a waitress and in some places it's then devided 
between waiters and cooks who worked that day. But the tipping here occurs 
in other buisness as well. Now I work in a doggy daycare and I'm getting 
tips when people are satisfied (and not arrogant) ;)

So yeah, that's it. Hope that help to have a closer look :) Have a nice day.
